Note: Participant notices that Meta does not do well with follow up questions and even when given context, Meta does not answer questions
Participant notices that Meta inaccurately assigns the tortoise statue as a real animal
Participant notices MR glasses perceive patterned table cover as a solid green, unable to discern patterns
When participant corrects Meta’s incorrect statement, Meta repeats its answer
Participant does not notice any difference in wearing the MR glasses in an indoor vs outdoor setting
Participant notices that volume gesture does not register
Participant notices that scrolling motion is working better in this session compared to previous sessions
Participant notes that brightness level of display in MR glasses is fine in the outdoor setting
Participant notices a rainbow glitch when they turn their head very quickly
Participant notices that they must keep adjusting glasses otherwise they will fall very low on nose bridge
Participant notices Meta cannot accurately identify acrylic nail art style (French tip)
Participant notices Meta incorrectly assumes they are asking questions about product pricing when asking about images in a poster
Participant notices that display lags behind information blurb
Participant notices that MR display adjusts itself to different lighting environments and is content with this as the screen is clear and visible under many lighting conditions
Participant feels like they lose their place in the line of text when reading through Meta responses
Participant notices an itchy sensation from neural band and believes the heat / sweat might be causing it
Image clarity in Meta prompts not the clearest, per participant
Participant notices Meta shifts it’s tone when answering certain follow-up questions and notices humanlike exhales
Participant does not notice any eye strain or discomfort so far into this study
Participant struggling to identify Lego pieces as image quality does not allow them to discern important details
Participant appreciates brightness level of MR display as an increase in brightness might reduce ability to see beyond screen
Especially as they are looking at display in MR glasses and simultaneously building Legos
Participant notices it is difficult to see image instructions in MR display while looking toward Legos because of all the different colors
Participant points eyes toward a solid background to see image instructions more clearly
Participant does not notice eye strain as they shift eyes from MR display to Lego set but does notice they must continually shift head to see images better
Participant expresses a desire to zoom in on images
Participant notices their eyes hurt when searching through loads of images especially as images are blurry before loading on WhatsApp
Participant was able to build Legos based on instructions much smoother than last time given the registration of scrolling gestures being captured more frequently
Participant struggling to perceive differences in color when looking at Lego pieces in image instructions
Participant feels embarrassment staring into space as they attempt to see the important details within image instructions, including color shade differences (light orange vs dark orange)
